questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is false regarding mosquitoes?

options.a: It is the definitive host in malaria
options.b: Mansonia is a vector for Malayan filariasis
options.c: Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
options.d: All mosquitoes can travel only for 100 metres

questions.explanation:
Most mosquitoes can travel or fly for distances up to 11 kms. 631 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: Which of the following species of mosquitoes breed in dirty water and water bodies 
containing aquatic vegetation respectively?
questions.explanation:
Culex species of mosquitoes breed mostly in dirty and polluted water. Mansonia species of 
mosquitoes breed in water bodies containing aquatic vegetation.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following statements is false about larva of mosquitoes?

options.b: Culex larva lies in water with head faced downwards
options.c: Anopheles larva lies parallel to the undersurface of water

questions.explanation: Anopheles larva has no siphon tube as shown in the image below. The image given below shows Culex larva having a siphon tube.

questions.question:
Question 4: Identify the species of mosquito shown in the image below. 623 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
632 
Sold by @itachibot The given image is of an Aedes mosquito. They can be identified with the stripes on the legs and body. They are also called tiger mosquitoes 
because of their stripes.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 25-year-old lady from a tribal area presented with fever, chills, vomiting, and abdominal 
pain for 4 days. The peripheral smear of the patient is given below. Which of the following is 
true about the mosquito which transmits this disease?

options.d: Keeps its body horizontal while feeding

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing ring form/ early trophozoites in 
erythrocytes are suggestive of Plasmodium falciparum malaria. It is transmitted by Anopheles 
mosquitoes. They have spotted wings. They breed in clean water. Their larva has no siphon tube and lies parallel to the undersurface of 
water. They tend to sit with their heads low and their rare ends raised high, especially when 
feeding.

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient presented with fever, headache, and retro-orbital pain for 3 days. He tested positive 
for the NS1 antigen. Which of the following mosquitoes transmits the disease he's suffering 
from?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with the positive NS1 antigen test is suggestive of dengue fever. 
It is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito, which is also called as tiger mosquito.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by Aedes mosquito?
questions.explanation: Japanese encephalitis and West Nile fever are transmitted by Culex mosquitoes. Chikungunya, yellow fever, and rift valley fever are transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.

questions.question:
Question 8: A banker who is scheduled to travel to Congo is advised to take the yellow fever vaccine. What 
is the flight range of the mosquito which transmits this disease?
questions.explanation: Yellow fever is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito. Its flight range is 100 metres.

questions.question:
Question 9: 625 
Sold by @itachibot A patient with fever and mucosal bleeding is diagnosed with dengue fever. Which of the 
following is false about the mosquito which transmits this disease?

options.b: Development of larva from egg does not require water
options.d: It has a striped body pattern

questions.explanation:
Dengue fever is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito. The conversion from the egg stage to the 
larval stage of this mosquito requires water. Eggs of any mosquito species do not survive without water. But the eggs of Aedes mosquitoes lie 
dormant in dry conditions for up to about nine months. They can hatch if exposed to favourable 
conditions such as water and food. 633 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of fever and headache for 5 days. 
Serological examination shows the presence of IgM antibodies to the JE virus. Which of the 
following mosquitoes transmits this disease?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Japanese encephalitis. It is transmitted by Culex 
mosquitoes like Culex tritaeniorhynchus

questions.question: Question 11: Match the following diseases and the mosquitoes which transmit them.

options.a: l - c, ll - a, lll - d, iV - b
options.b: l - a, ll - b, lll - c, lV - d
options.c: l - b, ll - c, lll - d, lV - a
options.d: l - d, ll - a, lll - b, lV - c

questions.explanation:
The correctly matched diseases with the mosquitoes which transmit them are: Disease 
Mosqu 
ito Yellow fever 
Aedes Bancroftian filariasis 
Culex Malaria 
Anoph 
eles Malayan filariasis 
Manso 
nia

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is true about pathogenic mosquitoes?
questions.explanation:
Aedes and Anopheles lay eggs singly. Culex lays eggs in rafts and Mansonia lays eggs in star-shaped clusters. Anopheles has spotted wings while the other pathogenic species have unspotted wings. Aedes transmits yellow fever, dengue and chikungunya. Culex is the main vector for JE and 
filariasis.

questions.question:
Question 13: You are posted in a PHC in a coastal region as a part of your rural postings. Which of the 
following Anopheles species is most commonly found here?
questions.explanation:
Anopheles stephensi and Anopheles sundaicus are found in coastal regions. Anopheles stephensi is also the main vector of malaria in urban regions. Anopheles culicifacies 
and Anopheles philippinensis are found in the plains. Anopheles fluviatilis and Anopheles 
minimus are found in foot-hill regions.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following species of Anopheles mosquitoes transmits urban malaria?
questions.explanation:
Urban malaria is transmitted by Anopheles stephensi. 634 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 15: What is the distance around an airport or seaport that has to be kept free of all mosquitoes?
questions.explanation:
The distance around an airport or seaport that has to be kept free of all mosquitoes is 400 metres. 
This helps in limiting the spread of vector-borne diseases to new geographic regions.

questions.question:
Question 16: Identify the following vector. 627 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: The given image is of a housefly, whose scientific name is Musca domestica.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is not a method of disease transmission by houseflies?
questions.explanation:
Houseflies do not transmit diseases by biting. They transmit diseases by mechanical transmission 
by their legs or feet, vomit drop, and defecation. They transmit a variety of diseases like: • Typhoid • Polio • Dysentery • Amoebiasis • Anthrax • Yaws

questions.question:
Question 18: Which disease is transmitted by the following vector that is found in cracks and crevices of 
walls in the day time? 628 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image is of a sandfly. It transmits visceral leishmaniasis. Note: Sandfly acts as a vector for the following diseases: • Kala-azar • Oriental sore • Sandfly fever • Oroya fever Japanese encephalitis is transmitted by the Culex mosquito. Dengue is transmitted by 
the Aedes mosquito. Trypanosomiasis is transmitted by the tsetse fly.

questions.question: Question 19: Sandfly does not transmit:
questions.explanation:
635 
Sold by @itachibot Trench fever is not transmitted by sandflies. It is transmitted by lice and caused by Bartonella 
quintana.

questions.question:
Question 20: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by the vector shown in the image given below? 629 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The vector shown in the image is a tsetse fly. It transmits African sleeping sickness (African 
human trypanosomiasis). Tsetse flies belong to the genus Glossina. They have not demonstrated insecticide 
resistance. Methods of tsetse fly control include spraying of DDT, clearing of vegetation, 
destruction of wild game and genetic control.

questions.question:
Question 21: A patient presents with blurring of vision and a painless swelling over his left elbow which 
has gradually been increasing in size over the past 1 year. On examination, he is noted to have 
patchy depigmentation on his legs. Which of the following vectors transmits the disease he's 
suffering from?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness. It is 
transmitted by blackfly. The usual presentation of onchocerciasis is the formation of a subcutaneous nodule or 
onchocercoma. It is a firm non-tender nodule arising from bony sites like the scalp, elbow, ribs, 
and iliac crest. It is associated with pruritus and rashes. Patients also present with patchy 
depigmentation on the legs called leopard skin. The presence of microfilaria in the eye causes photophobia and gradual loss of vision. The most 
severe manifestations are sclerosing keratitis and chorioretinitis which can lead to blindness. Blackfly is also called Simulium. It has a flight range of almost 100 miles, making control of adult 
flies difficult. Abate is widely used as a larvicidal insecticide. The image given below shows a 
blackfly. 636 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 22: Spot the wrongly matched arthropod and disease.
questions.explanation:
Blackflies (Simulium) are the vector for onchocerciasis and not Chaga's disease. An arthropod or an invertebrate that transmits infection is called a vector. It transmits infection 
by: • Inoculation into or through the skin or mucous membrane • Biting • Deposit of infective materials on skin or food or other objects Note: Chagas disease is transmitted by the reduviid bugs or kissing bugs or triatomines. 637 
Sold by @itachibot Medical Entomology - Ticks, Fleas and Mites
